one_reviews_text: A great video showing some history.
A beautiful and immersive experience. I love the way the scene changes from a movie theater, to the street, to inside the restaurant.

Rated 5 star so that it will most likely be seen im a little concerned i curious as to why they left so much of the tamir rice story out (the boy shot in the video in this documentory) the reason the police were called was from a concerned bystander that states that there was a man pointing a pistol at random people in the park. the caller also said repeatedly that the gun is probably fake and that the person was probably a juvinile however the 911 disbatcher never relayed this information to the responding police officers the "gun" was later found to be a black airsoft pistol nearly indestinguishable to a model 1911 the problem with it however is that the orange barrel tip indicating that it was a toy was missing pictures can be found online for those wanting to do there own research just wanted to provide an unbiased list of events not mentioned in the documentory hope you find this usefull and remember DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH not because there are wrong informatin being portraid because there is little to none here but because it should be a habit so you know your getting the full story and not spreading or believing only half truths

review_title: Not inaccurate but not the whole truth.
one_reviews_text:
Got this just to see if there were political messages. Not really but kind of. All the stories seem to be factual and quite sad. However, America is being blamed inaccurately as the reason for opressino. This ignores the fact that America, Republicans specifically have fought against slavery and the opression of all minorities throughout history. There is no better country on the planet where this is concerned. 
I saw a poster in descretely placed location while in VR while stories of opression were being told. The poster said  "Make America G###E Again". There was something ontop of the "Great" where you couldn't really see it. It really was not ment as a complementary thing. Overall, there are some valid historical points here but the full story of what needs to be told is conveniantly disreguarded. Because of this, it turns thin into a mild race bating propaganda piece which I was hoping it would not be. It's a discrase! If you want history, this is not for you. If you want to keep playing the victom and keep your hate alive, Hit play.
In these times you need context and this experience does just that.  Engaging story and well produced.

Powerful story, even for those familiar with the history.  4 stars instead of 5 because of the way it was filmed the people seated near you were hard to focus on and hurt my eyes despite me being very used to VR.  My advice is to only look across the table when you're seated in the booth, don't even try to look at the person next to you.

After watching this VR documentary I felt like I was really connecting with the people telling their stories. After watching this I saw that change is needed in our country. Watch this documentary. Watch it and see what was seen those days.

review_title: Watching this is necessary for everyone
one_reviews_text: Watching this during these difficult times in the world is more important than ever.  Only by understanding history can we see the progress we have made and have yet to make.  Great way of telling us about history and what is still going on today.  I hope there are more of these.

Ignore the negative reviews filled with bigotry and racism. This is never more relevant and needed for all white folk (I myself am a white male). Watch this.

If you can't watch it here, there is a pancake attempt w/ mouse navigation here: https://www.nytimes.com/video/opinion/100000006276181/traveling-black-us-greenbook.html

review_title: Complete Trash- not worth the DL
one_reviews_text: The stories of the people is not where the problem lays. The "VR experience is not an experience but a horrible attempt at it. The video movement is trash. It has this constant slow paced movement that may make you feel sick. If i could give it "no star" I would. The title is horrible. The elderly woman that you see repeatedly clearly is scripted dialog. I would have been ashamed to put this content out there.
the only problems i had was how it felt looking around in it my eyes actually hurt and i saw doubles of everthing and the way the world moves when you turn your head in the experince is very flawed.

I really really really wanna enjoy this expierence but it keeps glitching.  I tried to watch this exactly 12 times since yesterday but never once made it through the entire expierence cause the visuals get stuck indefintely at different points. Yesterday the furthest I got was the interview with 2 senior women in the diner. Today I cant even make it past the movie theatre intro.  It is NOT from my end cause every other game and expierence I have works just fine. Its only this. Please update this or something.

Also Racist people in the reviews, do everyone a favor and stfu. Your privelege is showing.

review_title: History classes should be taught in VR!
one_reviews_text: I agree with the content (even if you don't) this was superbly done.  Very powerful.  I love the perspective of you sitting in the booth listening to the stories of others.  More please!
This was a really good immersive documentery. I really thought the way the information was given was really helpful.
All the 1 star reviews are prob racists

When will all this racism end?!
A great VR experience!
This is important.
Must watch!
Very Good.

This short film truly displays the power of VR for cinema. Seamlessly merging documentary with magical-realist transitions into the past, often within the very same frame. 

The style and detail, from syncing in the same or different crowds in the restaurant to the effortless leaps between 2d and 3d film, is really staggering, and the fact it was produced in VR only drives the point home further. These are real people and their lives have been profoundly effected, they sit here with you telling you their stories and experiences-this is a feeling that, up to now, is exclusive to VR cinema.

It just pains me to read through many (not all) of the negative reviews here to see the exact forms of racism and bigotry the film is advocating against.

No, the space depicted is not a racist one. There are diners from many different ethnicities, and it is simply exploring the hardships endured by these real people.

Watch it, feel it, and experience it for yourself. But this is truly a heigh point for VR cinema.

review_title: How about traveling with a MAGA hat on.
one_reviews_text: You will be attacked, called every ist in the book, assaulted, treated like garbage, just for supporting the president. Being black is nothing, supporting Trump is as good as a death sentence.
Unless you can't stick Black or AfroAmerican people this is a must for all human beings. Only humans should apply.

This is nothing new if you took a 4th grade history class. Yes we know we were discriminated against, we know it was an awful time and how blacks were treated was despicable. I don’t need to be reminded of it all the time and don’t want my kids to keep seeing these kinds of things and feel bad about themselves. Production value was just ok, nothing great, really no reason to be VR and I’m a little surprised/offended that Oculus even has this in the store. It’s things like this, especially the Tamir Rice part at the end, that increases tension and divisions between blacks and whites, and it’s totally unnecessary.  If we keep on blaming white people for our problems, our problems will never go away.

Being Canadian, I did not know clearly about all of this and it opened up my mind  a lot.
The visuals are amazing, and they added so many tricks that make the video super refreshing and super creative.
Great job and thank you for this experience.

The background speech and video are in slow motion. Don't know why. Will give stars if I can sort it out.
***Update***
I have finally upgraded my CPU to a Ryzen (R7 2700X) and the problems with this app are a athing of the past.
This really is a masterpiece.
I will be getting my family and friends  to experience this too.

review_title: are you trying to divide people ???
one_reviews_text:
maybe you should be called CNN cause i dont know what is the purpose of making this crap but to divide people and promote hate between races

so i saw this and and thought it was about more historic events but its not.... the way its filmed is the best iv seen on here and it sad that its such a useless mesage..." f the cops everyone is innocent" ..i want to see more filmed like this but maybe a real subject and not a biast bit of anti police propaganda if u dont know anything about the travon thing and just went off what u see here its convincing ... but the 911 calls and all the important bits are not here how about ppl calling that he wans pointing a gun at them and then when u see the way he jumps up when the cop car pulls up  u can understand why they opened fire yea IDK why the cop pulled that close but it happned.nvm anyway filmed amazing with the cuts and locations but the msg is anti police and missing a lot of info about the topics it covers

This is the type of thing I really love to see in VR.  It is hard not to feel like you are in the room while the story is being told.  Usually I'm looking all over the place in VR to see what defects I can see, but having a room full of people looking at a speaker makes that tougher when you feel like you are sitting with them.  

The other thing that really impressed me were the small details like the reflections in the mirror either changing between time periods or removing people.  I almost didn't even notice that, but it really ephasized what was going on when I did.

I didn't know about the green book or the Tahir Rice shooting until watching this, which made it more engrossing as a white guy who isn't as familiar with these issues.  I saw another review point out the kid that was shot had an airsoft gun which I do feel changes that narative a bit, but I think the fear and separation that the green book was about is still felt in that story.  I still highly recommend watching it.

It's a very moving experience, especially in this era that racism and hatred crime raising after Trump got elected. VR can be a great tool to put people in different perspctive. We definitly need more videos like this.

This is an example of what VR can do that other media/museums/educational experiences cannot touch....it pulls you deeply into the narrative, centers your focus, lets you experience something from a different perspective, and packs a punch that is memorable and emotional.

This...this is the kind of stuff I love about VR.  Yes, I came here to kill zombies and shoot aliens, but I love learning.  Kudos to the devs, it is so important to know where we came from so that we can see how far we still have left to go.  If you read some of the negative reviews, you'll see what I mean.

This video looked good for a 360 video in VR. The environments were very cool and mood was great. Good compostion throughout. The menu setup is a little cludgy, but for what amounts to basically a 360 video, it's fine.

At the beginning they talk about the green book. That part of the story is fascinating and well laid out. Then they come to the story about Tamir Rice who was shot by the police, but if you don't know the story they leave out the fact that Tahir was holding an airsoft gun without the orange safety tip and had been pulling it out of his waistband and pointing it around prior to police arrival. It's still a shame what happened and the police did NOT handle the situation properly. Even though it was a story about racism the narrative never relates it back the green book or what it has to do with Traveling While Black which is supposedly the whole point of the documentary. I'm not denying that black people probably do face dangers today while traveling, but this story seemed just thrown in at random and to me totally distracted me from what should have been the real story and instead it was just a more generic, "these bad incidents happen to black people a lot". Which, while true, doesn't keep focus on the narrative. 

I wish they had modern stories today about traveling and dangers black people face in this video. Or being a VR story, actually have an experience of what it is like to walk down the street being black in an unfriendly neighborhood. But this Op-Ed chose not to do that and left me feeling as though it was lacking.

Oh, my.. this doc is so racist!
You can visit many times a real and crowded pub-restaurant  but you can't NEVER see even just ONE white person!
Stop with every racism, also racism towards whites!
Another poor example of liberal leftist ideology. White man is not the bad guy that they want you all to believe! And blacks are not the good guys that they want you all to believe. (and NO, you cannot go in ambulance with a injured, also if you are a white man!).
In this day and age we need more of this, using emerging technology to help people empathize with each other. I found this a moving story, and I for one am glad it is part of our ecosystem.
I don't see color.
This doesn't seem particularly ideological. In today's social climate, I'm thankful for such things. The major skew here is geometrical: we still don't have real live-action VR video.
Xjnzbn

This is an excellent documentary. The stories of traveling while black decades ago were awful. I wish they had kept the documentary about traveling while black instead of trying to live while black. The last story was heart breaking, but I could not understand what it had to do with traveling. It would have more impact to either relate the last story to the traveling theme more clearly or use a different story. That one point aside, it was still an amazing documentary. Also, it is better to view it on the Go. The video production uses lots of contrast, which creates really bad god rays on Rift, which is why I rated 4 stars instead of 5.

as a black man i truly felt this, great doc, I see all the one star reviews complaining about it, when they never went thru it!!! and save it with the race baiting crap, its our history that happended to us. Like they want us to forget out it! all you undercover racists make me sick

I have no words, but we need more of this. Especially in an age of rising divisions and intolerance we need to learn to love one another again. I won’t sit here and pretend I’ve faced the same challenges or ever faced segregation, but my heart breaks all the same. These are human beings, our brothers and sisters. We need to love, not hate.

This is a brilliant example of VR's potential to create empathy, providing a deeply movement experience that allows some sense of connection with the mistreatment of African-Americans, in the past and today.
It perhaps could have been a bit longer, since the scope is pretty large - covering several decades.  
It does rely a lot on visual effects to aid the storytelling - but the most powerful scenes don't rely on these.  In particular, the relatively simple scene in the diner where a mother recounts the death of her son is one of the most moving I have seen in any medium, and VR clearly adds to this.  This comes from the ability through VR to see not just the mother and her emotions but her audience of other diners, who have stopped what they are doing and are clearly deeply moved.

Powerful & riveting documentary by Roger Ross Williams and Felix & Paul Studios. It's about driving while black in America and I know this will probably get some hate from right wingers. However, it's beautifully shot and directed. You start off at what looks like a movie theatre and you're watching old, black & white 2D footage when suddenly you're transported into Ben's Chili Bowl, in Washington D.C.

It's shot 360 and you're put in the middle of the restaurant where you sit and listen to the voices in this community. I've never been to D.C. or this restaurant, but after this experience, I feel like I have been there. I'm not Black, but there is something about being in this chair and having the people talking directly in front of you. You feel like you're really there and you're part of this gathering and the stories are powerful and carry that much more weight. I definitely felt impacted by this experience.

If you look around at the mirrors you can see some differences. You also are put into a bus and there are scenes when you're in the empty restuarant with lighted images surrounding the darkness. The whole experience is a little less than 20 minutes long.

Amazing documentary that portrays a really sad reality in America. Documentary uses really well the 2D and 3D 360 video formats.  I have seen several 3D 360 videos and this documentary can contend for my favorite one.  It's such an immersive documentary !  I'm picky with what content I download and allow to occupy space in my hard drive and I'm definitely keeping this documentary in my library.  Did I mention it's free ? !

WoW...I've learned alot in my days but I have to admit I had never heard of the "Green Book" discussed in this documentary.  So surprised I'd never heard my family talk about either the Green Book or Bens Chili Dinner, especially since I live outside the DC metro area and worked in DC for over a decade.  Take a down time and enjoy this spectacular commentary about the dificulties black folks face living in America.....yesterday and still today.

More white racisist propaganda! Why is this crap even on here? Fleix an Paul are nothing but pedders of liberal leftist ideology. White man is not the bad guy that they want you all to believe! KEEP THIS CRAP OUT OF VR CHILL TIME! Shameful!

Being as though majority of my childhood was lived in Washington D.C., this hit close to home. And given the nature of the subject I shoudl've known what was or what could've been expected but my mind was else where at the time. And with that being said, Felix and Paul Studios have outdone theirselves yet again. Fair warning, there is at least one saddening story within this experience.

The quality and visual ideas are outstanding, giving this 20 minute documentary the attention it deserves. Being "there" brings it to another level - not just seeing, but experiencing has the effect of making topics like this more memorable. I am glad this exists - in VR, on the Oculus store, proving again that VR is so much more than just fun games or apps. That VR can be a powerful medium to reach people more directly than anything else. And as always, i cant wait to see what felix and paul, and all the other studios will show in the future - please never stop making this content!

Amazing on every level.   Fantastic technical quality,  amazing  script, and jaw-dropping editing and effects.  This is a very familiar subject, but this presentation is much more affecting than anything  I've seen - the intimacy  of the feeling of occupying the same space as the subjects somehow makes it seem so much less remote and abstract than is possible with traditional media.  Artful design frequently brings elements of the past into the present, so they're experienced simulataneously,.

This is an experience in VR (as if you couldn't tell from the title or description), not a game (for some of those expecting that). It's a first person POV in a life-like setting and told by the person who experienced it. The VR part is just to add to the immersion, which is does quite well. There was a lot of information in these life stories that I never knew people had to endure (it was quite shocking).

********SPOILER BEGIN******** One such example was when a child traveling 10 hours via train/bus, had to hold their bathroom breaks until they arrive to their final destination, hold it until they can stop somewhere to search for a spot in the wilderness (like an animal or something less than human) or until they can't hold it any longer and they have an accident right there in the seat of the train/bus (absolutely inhuman). ********SPOILER END********

TLDR:

Bottom line, it’s worth your time, either as a stark reminder of the cruelty of man or as an eye-opener to a reality that people had and continue to endure within a lifetime. I for one do not want this to be any human’s reality for the rest of existence and beyond.

As a White English man, I can't pretend to know what it's like, and from my perspective, a lot of the things that go in are hidden from society.  It's a sad state, that racism is still going strong in 2019.  Thanks for the education.
Rtihxf5
Having trouble playing this back, both audio and video are stuttering and unwatchable. System is running a GTX1080ti so shouldnt be a problem.
review_feedback: Hi Darren, thanks for letting us know about this issue. Could you send an email to QA@felixandpaul.com explaining the issue and including your CPU, GPU and OS? We'll be able to help you out from there.

one_reviews_text: Worth checking out! It's just a 20 minute experience, but the 360-degree video segments are well-implemented and it has a pretty powerful message.  It's best viewed as a seated experience though.
This video can cause nausea because it does not accurately reflect your body movements - be sure to sit very still when viewing.

Really well done, absolutely blew me away. Showcases how good 360 camera tech can make amazing short-films in VR. Loved the story and all the people, I also learnt about the challenges and dangers of Travelling Black in America. 5/5

It was well paced and had high production value. The video shots were well thought out and there were nice creative touches sprinkled throughout. Like the diner's reflection. VR has a unique ability to put someone face to face with individuals telling their stories. It's more compelling than a flat screen in many ways.

Why anyone would find this offensive is odd, and telling. One guy said he played games for fun, not to be "lectured". What? Did he think he was downloading Call of Duty or something? Bad faith reviews.
I loved it! We need more of this! This is why Oculus was made! Sadly we need to share the same place of games with all the idiotic people that belongs to it.
Video and sound in slow motion, and my pc beats by far the recommended specs.... I run all the vr end games and never had a problem like this.
review_feedback: Hi guilhermepaypal, thanks for letting us know about this issue. We are trying to reproduce it on our side. Could you send an email to QA@felixandpaul.com explaining the issue and including your CPU, GPU and OS? We'll be able to help you from there.

one_reviews_text: hard hitting documentary making very good use of virtual reality.

This short documentary teaces us of the past and pressent hardships suffered by the African American community. It allows you to sit face to face with human beings sharing their stories of the "American dream" and hear them, regardless of whether you see yourself or someone very different from you looking back from across the booth. This documentery should be shown in every school, luckly those communities which can afford such teaching implements are those who need to watch this the most!
Boring but informational, thought this was going to be some soverign citizen BS but it's not. Good game.

Your title screen depicts the most false narrative in history. A stick figure in the shape of a police officer, holding a pistol, standing at the door with the driver holding his hands up. All this makes me believe is that to be an African American or black male in society today, you must have a strong distaste for law enforcement. Hands up don't shoot; or perhaps, obey the law and don't commit violent felonies. Not one single person holding an oath seeks the day to take the life of another, especially for who they are or what they look like.

If this hadn't hosted such an awful front page image, I would have considered it an appropriate educational viewing. However, you sunk as low as you could get. Rise above the unsophisticated. One black sheep should not and cannot represent a population. Just as you shouldn't judge one man's actions on their race, ethnicity, age or gender.
Beautiful documentary. Need more of those
